review.title: Join-Graph Propagation Algorithms
review.abstract: The paper investigates parameterized approximate message-passing schemes that are based on bounded inference and are inspired by Pearl's belief propagation algorithm (BP). We start with the bounded inference mini-clustering algorithm and then move to the iterative scheme called Iterative Join-Graph Propagation (IJGP), that combines both iteration and bounded inference. Algorithm IJGP belongs to the class of Generalized Belief Propagation algorithms, a framework that allowed connections with approximate algorithms from statistical physics and is shown empirically to surpass the performance of mini-clustering and belief propagation, as well as a number of other state-of-the-art algorithms on several classes of networks. We also provide insight into the accuracy of iterative BP and IJGP by relating these algorithms to well known classes of constraint propagation schemes.

sections.text: We start with the limited inference mini-clustering algorithm and then move on to the iterative scheme called Iterative Join-Graph Propagation (IJGP), which combines both iteration and limited inference. IJGP belongs to the class of generalized belief propagation algorithms, a framework that allows connections to approximate algorithms from statistical physics and is empirically shown to exceed the performance of mini-clustering and belief propagation, as well as a number of other state-of-the-art algorithms across multiple classes of networks. We also provide insights into the accuracy of iterative BP and IJGP by linking these algorithms to known classes of restriction propagation programs.

sections.heading: 4. Join-Graph Decomposition and Propagation
sections.text: In this section, we will introduce the Iterative Join-Graph Propagation (IJGP) algorithm, which, like mini-clustering, is designed to benefit from limited inferences, but also take advantage of iterative message delivery as used by IBP. The IJGP algorithm can be considered an iterative version of mini-clustering, which improves the quality of the approach, especially for low i-limits. Given a cluster of decomposition, mini-clustering can potentially generate a different partitioning for each message sent to a neighbor. This dynamic partitioning can happen because the incoming message from each neighbor must be excluded from the realization of partitioning, so that a different set of functions for each message sent to a neighbor can be divided into mini-clusters. We can define a version of mini-clustering in which we create a unique static partition in mini-clusters for each cluster, so that each incoming message can be included in one of the mini-clusters.

sections.heading: 4.4 The Inference Power of IJGP
sections.text: Why is IJGP after convergence superior to IJGP with an iteration and superior to MC? An indication can be given when considering deterministic constraint networks, which can be considered as "extreme probabilistic networks." It is known that constraint propagation algorithms, which are analogous to messages by propagation, are guaranteed to converge and improve with iteration. IJGP's propagation scheme works much like constraint propagation relative to the flat network abstraction of the probability distribution (where all non-zero entries are normalized to a positive constant), and the propagation is guaranteed to be more precise for this abstraction. Below, we will shed some light on the behavior of IJGP by linking it to the well-known concept of arc consistency from constraint networks (Dechter, 2003). sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we examined a family of approximation algorithms for Bayesian networks that could also be extended to generic graphical models. We started with limited inference algorithms and proposed mini-clustering (MC) schemes as generalizations of mini-buckets to arbitrary tree decompositions. Its power lies in the fact that it is an i-bound parameter that can be set at any time. MC can start with small i-bound beliefs and increase them further as long as it is given more time, and its accuracy usually improves with more time. If given enough time, it is guaranteed to be accurate. One of its virtues is that it can also generate upper and lower limits, a route that is not explored in this paper. Inspired by the success of iterative belief propagation (IBP), we expanded MC into an iterative message transmission algorithm called iterative Join Graph Propagation (IGP), which can include iterative Iterative Propagation (GP) as opposed to Iterative GP (Iterative GP).
